reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the essay’s optimistic pathway: that partial AM-convergence plus trade/compromise (often illustrated via spatial/resource partitioning like “different galaxies”) can yield mostly-great outcomes. If non-separability is common—i.e., many values treat others’ practices anywhere as intrinsically disvaluable—then a large class of purportedly positive-sum moral trades collapses into contests over universal prohibitions, undermining the compromise-based optimism (centrality ~0.65). The argument has real force, especially against the flagship “resource-splitting buys near-best for each side” picture and against optimism that “hybrid goods” generally rescue bargaining; it identifies a structural assumption (separability) that isn’t made explicit. However, the position already anticipates related failure modes (negative-leaning views, heavy bad-weighting, threats/extortion, low resource-compatibility among linear views), so the critique is partly “priced in,” and doesn’t fully refute the essay’s broader claim that trade can sometimes help under certain conditions (strength ~0.55). Most claims are conceptually correct, but it overstates by implying the framework effectively requires separable welfarism and that dropping non-separable views would substantially blunt ‘no easy eutopia’ (correctness ~0.75). The critique is clear, focused, and has minimal fluff (clarity high; dead weight low; single-issue high). Overall it poses a meaningful but not decisive problem.
title: Non-separable values make galaxy-splitting compromises impossible
